Award.AwardTitle: Multitrophic Consequences of Novel Plant Assemblages in Urban Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants and animals from other continents have been intentionally or accidentally brought to the U.S. for centuries. Many of them have become established, creating ecosystems made of species that have never before interacted with each other. Horticultural preferences have transformed the native plant communities that once supported life in residential landscapes into a collection of introduced plants that have no history with native organisms. If introduced plants are the ecological equivalents of the native plants they replace, ecosystem function in managed landscapes will remain as high as in natural areas. But if introduced plants do not support life as well as native plants, the diversity of animals where humans work, live and farm (well over 50% of the U.S. land area) will be reduced. This would be unsustainable because biodiversity drives ecosystem function, and functional ecosystems produce the natural services that sustain human populations. This project addresses the ability of plants to support food webs by comparing food webs in residential landscapes comprised of native plants with food webs in landscapes built from introduced plants. The research focuses on birds and their insect prey because both are excellent indicators of food web stability and diversity, and thus of overall biodiversity. Using Carolina chickadees, the study will measure how landscapes created from Asian plants alter: 1) insect communities; 2) the diets of nesting chickadees; and 3) the breeding success of chickadees in residential landscapes.

This study integrates outreach with science by conducting research on properties enrolled in Neighborhood Nestwatch, a citizen science program. Results will be published in the primary and popular literature to target landowners and policy-makers at all levels of environmental expertise. The public lacks an understanding of how plants and the insects that eat them enable more charismatic vertebrates, such as birds, to exist in urban environments. This study will help provide such understanding, which is key to sustainability because it is the public who will determine what urban ecosystems will look like in the future. In the process of this research, students will be trained in ecology and equipped with the skills needed to tackle major environmental challenges in the future.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we used Carolina chickadee to test six hypotheses 1)Plant species origin (native vs non-native) determines the abundance and diversity of caterpillars (bird food); 2)Plant quality (ability to produce caterpillars) determines the abundance and diversity of breeding birds; 3)parent bird foraging behavior and nestling diet (ratio of caterpillars to other arthropods) are determined by the origin of landscape plants; 4)The caterpillar component of nestling diet in chickadees will increase as the biomass of native landscape plants increases; 5)Reproductive success and annual survival in Carolina chickadees is positively correlated with the biomass and insect productivity of landscape plants 6)Nestling health and growth rate is determined by the percentage of caterpillars nestling diet.

We found that, compared to suburban yards dominated by native plants, yards dominated by introduced plants (non-native ornamental species) produced 75% few caterpillars and were 60% less likely to have breeding chickadees take up residence. If chickadees did choose to nest in yards dominated by introduced plants, their nests contained 1.5 fewer eggs, were 29% less likely to survive, produced 1.2 fewer fledglings which took 1.5 days longer to mature. We also documented that chickadees in landscapes dominated by nonnative plants attempt to compensate for the loss of high quality caterpillar food by increasing consumption of low quality food items such as spiders and aphids, but this diet switch has serious costs for offspring health and dramatically increases how hard adults have to forage for food (number of trips to the nest). Population growth models of these data show that chickadee populations were unsustainable in yards containing more than 20% introduced plants. Our studies show that suburban yards in the east range average from 56% to 79% nonnative plants.  

This project provides a blueprint for the future of conservation in human-dominated landscapes. It documents that native plants with coevolved relationships that determine the amount of insect biomass available for bird reproduction cannot be replaced by nonnative plants that have no coeveolved relationships without seriously reducing the ability of birds to breed successfully. Because 83% of the U.S and 85.6% of the U.S. east of the Mississippi river is privately owned, successful conservation efforts must include privately owned properties. If those properties are not landscaped with productive native plants, insect abundance and diversity plummets, and so does the abundance and diversity of the birds that depend on those insects. With populations of 432 species of North American birds declining so rapidly that they are now considered at risk of extinction, nationwide efforts to improve the integrity and productivity of human-dominated ecosystems are in order. Our research suggests the mechanisms for these declines and ways that we can reverse these declines. We believe the future of conservation is in thehands of private property owners across the U.S.


Last Modified: 04/06/2018
Modified by: Douglas W Tallamy
